title: Typo: remaining->reset
body:
## This PR

fixes a typo.

title: Split quota-policy definition. Allow comments.
body:
## This PR

- splits quota policy definition from RateLimit-Limit
- allows custom parameters in quota-policy, like 'burst', 'policy' or 'comment'
- introduces the concept of 'quota-unit' to nicely replace 'request'

title: Remove allow, disentangle from actual requests per second.
body:
## This PR

Contains better wording.

title: Adds an example with remaining: 0
body:
## This PR

Shows an example of `ratelimit-remaining: 0` within a successful response.

title: Avoid the `allow` word
body:
## I expect

The spec to avoid stating anything such as

> The client is allowed to issue ...

## This is because

The returned counters don't imply that the client is "allowed".

It's up to the server to decide whether the returned counters imply that the client is "allowed" or not.

title: Fix: #44. First Limit must always be an integer.
body:
## This PR

- Fixes #44 
- the first value of `Limit` is an integer. Subsequent values must define a window.

title: Should the first `Limit` item always be an integer?
body:
## The case

Consider the following policy and an incoming rate of `0.9 rps`

```
Limit: 10;w=10,   15;w=20
```

The returned headers will be

```
-- after 10 second
Limit: 10;w=10,  15;w=20
Remaining: 1
Reset: 1

-- after 16 seconds
Limit: 10;w=10,  15;w=20
Remaining: 1
Reset: 4
```

## The problem

After 16 seconds, the client doesn't know which is the underlying window.

## Solutions

### Hp1: `Limit` should be an ordered list, with the first field matching the values in `Reset` and  `Remaining`

example:

```
-- after 16 seconds
Limit: 15;w=20,   10;w=10
Remaining: 1
Reset: 4
```

pro:
- allows using window informations in Limit
- it is always clear which window is exhausted first

cons:
- complex to implement for server and client

### Hp2: first `Limit` item can't support window.

example:

```
-- after 16 seconds
Limit: 15,   10;w=10,   15;w=20
Remaining: 1
Reset: 4

```

pro:
- simple to implement
- clients can just ignore al the `Limit` values after the `,` and work anyway
- client can parse and get the quota searching by the window

cons:
- can't specify the `time-window' when a single `request-quota' is used
- a duplicate `request-quota` value is used.

title: Rename the `window` parameter to `w`
body:
## Consider to

- [ ] rename the `window` parameter to `w` for brevity

title: Define headers dependencies
body:
## I expect

The spec to define header inter-dependencies 


## Hypothesis

- [ ] Remaining -> Reset
- [ ] Limit -> Reset
- [ ] Limit, Remaining, Reset


## Note

Do I have to expose *all headers* or I can only expose a subset?
Do we need to add some considerations on client implementation?

title: Define an upper bound for RateLimit-Reset
body:
## I expect

The `delta-seconds` used for `RateLimit-Reset` to have an upper bound.

This could help with #15 because we could say that:

- if the value is higher than `x` it could be processed as an UNIX Timestamp.

## Notes

Could 2 days be enough? (eg. 48*3600). 

I don't expect issues if I don't respect a 2-day request-quota, though this choice is really arbitrary;

title: Fix #26. Security considerations for Reset and Remaining.
body:
## This PR

adds security consideration and validation.

title: Move gory details about current headers to the appendix. See #32

Simplifies the Introduction and moves details to an appendix that may be
removed during the publication phase.

title: Fix #33. Use delta-seconds.
body:
## This PR

Use delta-seconds instead of delay-seconds.

This clarifies unsigned integers and poses some questions on processing overflowing numbers

Removes the `X-` suggestion for draft implementations.

See #36

title: Don't bother with `X-`
body: This is just going to confuse matters.

title: Structured Headers
body: It would be great if these could be defined as structured headers.

title: Header names
body: `RateLimit-Limit` is not a great name... suggest making them more concise.

title: delta-seconds
body: you define `delay-seconds`, but could just use `delta-seconds` from RFC7234.

title: Remove extraneous information
body:
The background in 1.2 and 1.4 are too much information for a spec; it'd be best to either move them to a different document (e.g,. a Wiki), or to an appendix that's removed by the RFC Editor before publication.

- [x] simplify the [1.2 Current landscape of ratelimit headers](https://ioggstream.github.io/draft-polli-ratelimit-headers/draft-polli-ratelimit-headers.html#rfc.section.1.2) and move the rest to an appendix #39  

- [ ] simplify [1.4 Goals](https://ioggstream.github.io/draft-polli-ratelimit-headers/draft-polli-ratelimit-headers.html#rfc.section.1.4)

align header syntax.

header definition matches RFC 7231, eg

```
     Location = URI-reference
```

header field syntax is already defined in HTTP

the `throttling` paragraph to be in the intro

title: Always validate `RateLimit-Reset`
body:
## I expect

- [x] clients MUST validate `RateLimit-Reset` and MAY retry before if the proposed value is too high;
- [x] clients MUST validate `RateLimit` value
- [x] security considerations: `RateLimit` value may be artificially altered by a malicious intermediary to trigger DoS

title: Param vs unparam examples
body:
## This PR

Splits examples of parameterized and un-parameterized responses.
Replace `interval` with `time-window`.
Clarify `Reset` semantics.

title: Redefine ratelimit 1
body:
## This PR

Define ratelimit values in term of request-quota, which is:

* related to - but different from - the maximum number of requests;
* dependent from the throttling basis (ip, user, geo, ..)

## This PR

Adds FAQs on SLA and using weights on requests.

removes trailing spaces and fixes typos.

title: Fix: #2. Rationale of delta-seconds.
body:
## This PR

improves the rationale of delta-seconds.
TODO: add "caching" considerations.

title: Lexical improvements.
body:
## This PR

Introduce some lexical improvements.

title: Consider using UNIX-Timestamp instead of HTTP Date for `RateLimit-Reset`
body:
## Question

Currently we have

```
ratelimit-reset-value = Retry-After
Retry-After =  HTTP-Date | delta-seconds
```

Instead we could

```
ratelimit-reset-value = UNIX Timestamp | delta-seconds
```

### pro

- simpler to generate and to parseintroduces parsing confu
- compatible with many current implementations (twitter/github)


### cons

- misaligned with `retry-after`;
- could incentive using an absolute time instead of delta-seconds;
- may confuse parsers, as both formats have the same syntax; An arbitrary solution could be
  to state that the max value for delta-seconds is 86400 or a reasonable high value.
- y2k38 problem for UNIX-time as a `32 bit signed integer`  

## Notes

-  We could state something on too-high values in `ratelimit-reset` in the security considerations, though HTTP specs does not seem to contain any of that.
- We could even enforce ONLY `delta-seconds`

title: Fix: #3. Use in throttled responses.
body:
## This PR

Describes use in throttled responses.

Add an example of consistency between `RateLimit-Reset` and `Retry-After`.

title: Fix: #10. Avoid usually.
body:
## This PR

avoids usually

title: WIP: Major rework + thoughts
body:
## This PR

- moves a narrative part in the introduction
- adds more normative parts.

To avoid that this spec could suggest any SLA (eg. that the `Remaining` value is a `guaranteed` one) it is explicited that:

- the provided values are the ones used to evaluate the quota on the executed request, and they may 
not provide any guarantee that future requests may benefit those values.

This does not mean that an implementor may provide a guaranteed value for `Remaining` or `Reset`, but just that the spec does not mandate it.

title: refine text
body:
## This PR

- out of scope: failing requests counting on quota
- clarify that the client is never allowed to make requests

body:

To avoid `usually`

title: Explicit that the values exposed are used for computing the current request, not the future ones
Informative references via curly braces.
body:
## This PR

moves informative references to curly braces inline notation.

title: Scope of ratelimit headers and "caching"
body:
## I expect

the spec to contain the following considerations:

- `RateLimit-*` headers should not be cached nor considered persistent in any way;
- if I got a `RateLimit-Reset` response stating that the reset window expires on `Wed, 31 Jul 2019 00:00:00 GMT` further requests MUST NOT give for granted that this value is still valid for further requests.

Example

```
TBD

```

title: Suggestion on multiple windows.
Suggest implementors to use  `X-RateLimit` during the draft- phase
body:
## Hint

Until `RateLimit-*` is not an RFC, we could suggest implementors 
to use `X-RateLimit-*` instead all along the `draft-` phase.

title: Should Authorization to be included in the goals
body:
## Question

Authorization is currently out of scope for this spec

Q1: Should that be in-scope, considering that some implementations returns `403` when 
a user is over-quota?

Q2: In that case, what should be added to the Security Considerations?

title: Describe use in throttled requests
body:
## I expect

A description on how to use RateLimit-* in throttled responses, eg `429`

## example

An user over quota, and receives an eg 429.

Returning all the headers may be redundant, as

- RateLimit-Remaining == 0
- RateLimit-Reset == Retry-After

Not returning the triple may make things complex for client

```
GET /foo

HTTP/1.1 429 Too Many Requests
RateLimit-Limit: 1
RateLimit-Remaining: 0
RateLimit-Reset: 58
Retry-After: 58
```

## Questions and proposals

Q1- "the server MAY return all three headers?" or  `the server SHOULD return all three headers` ?

Q2 - "Retry-After MUST be equal to RateLimit-Remaining"

title: Improve rationale  of delta-seconds choice respect to timestamp.
body:
## I expect

To improve  the rationale of chosing  using delta-seconds instead of timestamps (whether HTTP-Date or UNIX-Timestamp).

Clarify that using timestamps may be subject to some sort of caching.

## Currently

We explained the consistency with retry-after and the clock-skew safety

title: Improve description of current API rate-limiting landscape.
body:
## I expect

The introduction on the current throttling landscape to be more comprehensive
and detailed.
